title: This finals was an amalgamation of everything that's wrong with season 9.
body:
Way too much damage and a perma gank meta where Lee Sin loses out on nothing by spending more time setting up ganks than farming.

The damage being way over the top.

Vision being gutted to the point where it's way too easy for jungle pressure to turn the tables.

Even pro players suffering from the effects of "top lane being camped" with the losing bot still being nigh on hopeless for the top laner to try and carry.

And don't forget Lee Sin and Kaisa being absolute cancer to play against but have been left unchecked for some reason.

This finals was an amalgamation of everything that's wrong with how impactful jungle is in invalidating teams and how easy it is to set top laners behind merely by forcing them to "play safe". Turret plating leading to uncontrollable snowballs, and sky high damage which makes this into a game of seek and destroy.

The problem is both of them are right, for exactly the same reason Riot keeps Kalista dumpstered; what is good in SoloQ and what is good as a 5-man with comms are very much not the same thing. 

In SoloQ playing jungle is an absolute shit-show where you have to be able to on your own carry yourself plus up to 3 other lanes; in 5-man the entire team functions as one, and as such the jungler can have a huge amount of impact. In Solo your Top will most likely cry at you if they get camped, even if you use that presence to focus drake and the Bot-side; in 5-man the Top usually recognises the advantage keeping the enemy jungler near them gives and plays around it.

Basically, it's the fact that if something more supportive is really viable in SoloQ, it is truly oppressive in 5-man (see Sejuani, Galio at his low points, Kalista, most other tank Junglers); to keep things that require coordination balanced in 5-man they basically HAVE to suck to play Solo. And since most of the Boards are Solo players, most of what you'll see on here is 'Jungle is so bad to play!'

So, is the solution to this problem to clearly keep champions SoloQ or pro play viable?
The thing with OP's thread then is that the complain is that Lee Sin is clearly OP because G2 lost 3 games consecutively by letting him get picked by FPX. So is he the same problematic champion in soloQ or is the OP only complaining about the "boring" 3 games he watched during Worlds?

If Riot's guilty of "forcing" flashy champions into the meta, why is also the Boards so adamant and complaining to Riot when Sejuani was viable? So they wanted to remove a champion from the meta, because they're tired seeing her in every game. But i guess that is only OK when the Boards demand it, not when Riot decides to put a champion in.

I'd really like to know where this golden middle of balance is, how much champions are allowed to assist or farm and yet, not stomp on someone's toes too hard and be actually "boards' balance approved". Because my belief is that no such middle exists.

You can't have champions who are in the exact middle because they end up being jack of all trades and masters of none. Champions who have a little bit of everything in their kit in order to have an option to respond to different situations and end up being problems for balance because they have too much stuff.

Lee is THE example of where Riot have gone severely wrong; because his plays are so flashy, they are willing to let him sit far above the bar in terms of balance. He is pretty free LP in Solo/Duo if you can play him; because of his stats and scalings he has a low skill floor for the height of his skill ceiling (i.e. it's not hard to do well with him, and played properly he destroys games).

Whilst this is a problem, he generally doesn't have too much Boards hate because he used to have a proper risk-reward ratio (back when inSec made a name for the ward-hop-into-R play); his bullshit status is due to Riot wanting more plays like that to be possible even with power and mobility creep.

Seju is not a risky in-and-out style champion; she hard engages, ults a carry to lock them down for the team, then just sits there absorbing damage; when she is viable in Solo (i.e. doesn't require team backup to have an effect on the game) she feels like facing a wall that fell on you. 

Lee and Seju are the difference between being hit by a thrown rock and a thrown knife; both will hurt, both require skill, but for some reason one feels like it needs more skill than the other.

No, the solution is to fucking provide voice chat so the jungler can actually tell you he's going for the dragon so you can hold the opponent jungler hostage top side by playing passive-aggressive.

This isn't a team based game without voice chat, no matter how much you guys may hate the idea.

You don't have to die or even burn flash to a gank for that gank to seriously ruin your entire lane.
If the enemy jungler is topside you now can't contest the wave, your opponent can do whatever they want with it. They can now stack up 3 waves in a huge slowpush and have the jungler come and dive you.

Even if you ward everything out, read the dive and back off you're still losing:
3 entire waves under tower(450ish gold, more than half a level in XP early)
probably 2 plates if your opponent has demolish(320 gold)

So now you're down 770 gold, more than 2 and a half kills worth of gold AND xp and the jungler hasn't even touched you.
The only dragon that's even remotely worth it in this situation is Infernal, mountain isn't even that great in soloQ because people don't play around baron in the same way. Because towerdiving is so easy you can't just stay under tower and try to outplay the dive, you have to back off all the way to your tier 2 and cry as you miss a ton of gold and experience.  Voice chat would in no way fix this issue, it would just piss people off when their lane is 100% over at 0/0/0 and the jungler just says "dw guys I got ocean drake xd".

The Voice Chat exists but only for premades.
And that was done due to Riot not having systems in place to moderate voice chat, in the same manner as they can do with written chat.

I personally think Stopwatch is the most cancerous thing to happen to league in a while.  I've always been fine with Zhonya's because you have to dedicate your build to it. But when everyone on the enemy team has one, it can be such a game changing item for a mere 600 gold (or for free if you have the rune). I can't think of any other item in the game that can potentially have such a massive impact, such as turning a critical teamfight (i.e. AD carry getting caught out of position) or causing a dive to go horribly wrong.

I'm on the fence with having it as a shop item since unless you are building toward a Zhonya's, you are setting yourself behind in your build. However, I always thought that runes were meant to be minor/moderate enhancements to your champ, but not something that should make or break the outcome of a game. It's not even a keystone so you aren't really sacrificing much to have it.

I think stopwatch as an item (or at the very lease, the rune) needs to be removed. What scares me is the chance that Riot decides to just give one to everyone. They did that with gold generation several seasons ago... when everyone was buying phil stone and heart of gold (and in some cases avrice blade), they just removed the items and increased gold generation across the board. In a way they did that with wards by giving everyone trinkets.

Granted that a lot of people don't always use it optimally, kinda like how someone burns their flash when they are guaranteed to die anyways. However, it does kinda reward poor play by letting people get caught out of position and not get aptly punished for it as well as not rewarding well-planned plays like ganks/dives simply because someone got a free item for doing but play for 10 minutes.

Maybe I am just overreacting to seeing it being used at games where the highest level of play is on display, but for something that potentially powerful to cost 600/free just doesn't sit well with me.
